conversations.content: The Purehearted Maiden: Part One
I can only imagine the legends you may have heard about we unicorns, Euden.
In these tales, we are noble, single- horned dragons who scorn human contact save for the purehearted maidens to whom we are in thrall.
There are even minstrels who sing of us as lustful deviants—an untruth which I find most depressing.
Perhaps such shameless unicorns did exist once, but it would be most terrible for us all to be painted with that same brush of dishonor.
There is no denying our love of purity, but one need not be a virgin maiden to claim that status—that is far too simplistic a way to look at things.
If you desire proof, listen now to the story of my father. This tale will give you a better idea for the kind of purity we seek.
Long ago, there was a purehearted princess in Alberia. At her father's order, she married a noble with outstanding parentage but a heart most wicked.
Yet it never occurred to the maiden to doubt her husband's faithfulness, for sadly purity oft renders one blind. And here does our story truly begin...
The Purehearted Maiden: Part Two
Let me resume my story of the pure maiden beloved by my father.
She was an Alberian princess who married a noble, unaware that his heart was filled with a lust for power.
When he tried and failed to usurp the throne, it came as a shock to his wife. Yet her husband's retainers tried to convince the crown that it was she who first suggested this vile plan.
Their deception was successful—but on the way to the execution, her carriage was attacked by wolves. She escaped, but was injured doing so, and soon found herself lost.
It was then that a noble unicorn—my father—found her. He kneeled down, placed his horn under her, and lifted her back to her feet.
The princess was shocked to be saved by a unicorn. ＂I'm no pure maiden,＂ she said, ＂but a fool who couldn't see through her husband's duplicity.＂
＂Is that so?＂ said my father. ＂Because your soul looks more pure than any I have ever seen.＂ And with that, he set her on his back and they hurried for the palace.
Her appearance caused an uproar, for a noble unicorn would never have partnered with a guilty maiden. Thus was her honor restored, and the true criminals revealed.
Father always supported married  women and widows above all. It wasn't some manner of fetish—he just knew their hearts were pure. And like him, I also have no such obsession.
Incidentally, you seem to have rather a lot of young maidens in your vicinity. ...How do I know, you ask? Why, I can smell them on you!
Purity is determined by the soul above all else. But sometimes immoral acts can sully the character of even the purest young man—and what a terrible waste that is!
I simply cannot stand back and let that happen. So be careful around women other than me!
